ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Under-amplification due to earmold acoustics
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Patient reported poor sound quality and audibility; REM confirmed gain was significantly below NAL-NL1 targets due to new earmolds and software incompatibility prevented digital adjustment.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To determine hearing thresholds for gain target calculation.
To rule out middle ear pathology.
To account for individual ear canal acoustics in gain calculations.
To verify hearing aid gain against prescriptive targets before and after modification.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: The patient presented with mild to moderately severe SNHL and normal middle ear function. Verification measures revealed that the hearing aids with new earmolds were significantly under-amplifying speech relative to NAL-NL1 targets. RECD measurements indicated smaller than average ear canals. Physical modifications to the earmolds were performed to improve the gain response.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Bilateral mild to moderately severe sensorineural hearing loss; symmetrical configuration (Right AC thresholds: 250Hz 35, 500Hz 40, 1000Hz 50, 2000Hz 55, 4000Hz 65, 8000Hz 70 dB HL).

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Good word recognition ability at elevated levels (Right WRS 96% at 80 dB; Left WRS 92% at 80 dB).

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.result_summary: Normal middle ear function (Type A) bilaterally.

tests.name: Real Ear to Coupler Difference (RECD)
tests.result_summary: Measured values deviate from average, indicating smaller ear canals (e.g., 13.7 dB at 4000 Hz vs average 10.0 dB).

tests.name: Real Ear Measures (REM)
tests.result_summary: Pre-modification REIG was 8-12 dB below NAL-NL1 targets. Post-modification REIG approximated targets well, particularly in high frequencies.

proposed_items: Reduce earmold vent size from 2mm to 1mm to increase low-frequency gain
Add 3mm Libby horn to increase high-frequency gain
Insert 1500 Ohm damper to smooth mid-frequency peaks
counseling_actions: Inform patient that modifications are a temporary solution for travel
Advise follow-up with original audiologist for fine-tuning upon return home
Explain that software incompatibility necessitated physical acoustic modifications

escalation.rationale_short: Patient needs permanent programming/fine-tuning which requires the specific manufacturer software available at her home clinic.

follow_up_plan.objective: Fine-tuning with original audiologist using manufacturer software.

expected_outcome: Patient reported a marked increase in her ability to understand speech.
Post-modification Real Ear Insertion Gain (REIG) better approximated NAL-NL1 targets in the high frequencies compared with the unmodified target gain.
